title: How to Make a Mermaid Skirt

steps.headline: Take your child's measurements.
steps.description: Use a tape measure to measure around your child's hip. Next, measure from your child's waist down to his or her ankle. Record these measurements. You may be able to get this method to work for an adult skirt, but you may have to adjust the proportions. An adult's figure will be curvier than a child's.

steps.headline: Cut a rectangle out of stretchy fabric for the body of the skirt.
steps.description: The width of the rectangle needs to be 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) shorter than your waist measurement. The length of the rectangle needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) shorter than your waist-to-ankle measurement. Make sure that the length of the rectangle goes with the grain of the fabric, or it won't stretch right. For a more mermaid-like skirt, go for a pretty shade of green. Bonus points if it has a scale print!

steps.headline: Cut a skinny rectangle for the ruffling.
steps.description: This will be the bottom portion of the skirt. It needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) tall and twice the width of your skirt body. You can use the same fabric in the same color or a coordinating one. For something that looks more like a mermaid tail, try a sheer fabric, such as organza or chiffon.

steps.headline: Cut a skinny rectangle for the waistband.
steps.description: It needs to be 4 inches (10.6 centimeters) tall and the same width as your skirt body. The length of the skinny rectangle needs to run along the grain of the fabric. You must use the same type of fabric as you did for the body of the skirt. It can be a different color, however.

steps.headline: Fold the skirt and ruffle pieces in half.
steps.description: Fold the skirt body in half lengthwise with the long ends matching up. Fold the ruffle piece in half widthwise with the narrow ends matching up.

steps.headline: Cut a curve into the bottom corner of both pieces.
steps.description: Place the folded ruffle piece on top of the folded skirt body. Make sure that the bottom corners (opposite the folded corner) match up. Cut the bottom corner off so that it is rounded instead. The curve needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) tall on both pieces. Try to cut through all four layers of fabric at the same time so that they match up. If the fabric is too thick, cut one piece first, then use it as a guild to cut the other. If you are having troubles getting a nice curve, use a plate, bowl, or lid as a guide.

steps.headline: Sew two rows along the top, straight edge of the ruffle piece.
steps.description: Unfold the ruffle piece. Sew a straight stitch along the top, straight edge using a ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) seam allowance. Sew another one just below it using a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) seam allowance. Use the longest stitch length you can.

steps.headline: Gather the ruffle fabric.
steps.description: Find both of the bobbin threads on one side of your ruffle piece. Gently pull on it to start gathering your fabric. Keep gathering until it is the same length as the bottom, curved edge of your skirt body. From time to time, you may have to switch over to the other side of the ruffle piece. Remember to pull on the bobbin threads!

steps.headline: Pin and sew the ruffle piece to the skirt piece.
steps.description: Place the ruffle piece on top of the skirt body, right sides together. Match up the gathered edge of your ruffle with the curved bottom edge of the skirt body. Pin them in place, then sew them together using a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) seam allowance. Remove the pins as you sew. If you are using jersey fabric, you don't need to serge it. If you are using fabric that frays, it might be a good idea to serge it or go over the edges using a zigzag stitch.

steps.headline: Sew the sides of the skirt together.
steps.description: Fold the ruffle down so that the hem is against the skirt body. Fold the skirt in half, with the right sides facing in and the long edges matching up. Sew along the side of the skirt using a 1/2-inch (1.27-centimeter) seam allowance. Stop and backstitch when you reach the ruffle. Don't sew the ruffle edges together.

steps.headline: Fold the waist band in half, then sew the narrow ends together.
steps.description: Fold the waistband in half widthwise, with the right sides facing in and the narrow ends matching up. Sew along the narrow edge using a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) seam allowance. Your waist band should now be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) tall and the same width as your skirt. For a neater finish, spread apart the seam and press it flat with an iron.

steps.headline: Fold the tube in half to make it narrower.
steps.description: Working around the circumference of your waistband, start folding the top edge down towards the bottom. When you are done, you should have a 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) tall tube that is the  same width as your skirt.

steps.headline: Pin and sew the waistband to the skirt body.
steps.description: Keeping the skirt turned inside-out, tuck the waistband into it. Make sure that the raw edges match up. Pin the waistband in place, then sew it using a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) seam allowance and a stretch stitch. Remove the pins as you sew. If your sewing machine doesn't have a stretch stitch, use a zigzag stitch instead.

steps.headline: Turn the skirt inside out.
steps.description: Pull the waistband upwards and press it flat with an iron. If you want to, you can topstitch the hem down using a stretch stitch. Your little mermaid's skirt is ready to wear!

steps.headline: Buy 2 yards (1.8 meters) of stretchy fabric.
steps.description: It does not matter if the fabric is 44 inches (111.76 centimeters) or 60 inches (152.4 centimeters) wide. A mermaid skirt is a type of skirt, so you can use any color or print you want; it does not have to look like a mermaid's tail.

steps.headline: Cut it along the fold.
steps.description: When you buy fabric off the bolt, it will be folded in half. Cut along this top fold so that you have two panels of fabric that are 2 yards (1.8 meters) wide.

steps.headline: Cut the fabric down to the right length, if needed.
steps.description: Measure from your hips down to your ankles, or wherever you want the skirt to end. Add 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) to that measurement for the top and bottom hem allowances. Measure your fabric and cut it down, if needed. Make sure that it's still 2 yards (1.8 meters) wide.

steps.headline: Fold the fabric in half widthwise.
steps.description: Your fabric should now only be 1 yard (0.9 meters) wide and four layers thick.

steps.headline: Fold a pencil skirt in half and place it on top of your fabric.
steps.description:
Align the folded edge of your skirt with the folded edge of the fabric. The top edge of the skirt should be about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) below the top edge of the fabric. If you don't have a pencil skirt, do the following:
Measure around your hips and knees, then divide both measurements by 4. Use your new hip and knee measurements to make points x-inches/centimeters away from the folded edge of your fabric. Make sure that the distance between your hips and knees matches up. Connect the lines using a dress maker's chalk or pen.

steps.headline: Cut the fabric using the skirt as a guide.
steps.description: Use a 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) seam allowance. Stop when you reach where the knees are on your pencil skirt. If you don't have a pencil skirt, cut 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) outside the line that you drew.

steps.headline: Cut at angle from the knees down to opposite bottom corner of the fabric.
steps.description: This will make the flared part of your skirt. Is you need to, use a straight edge and a dress maker's chalk or pen to draw a guideline first.

steps.headline: Unfold and stack your fabric.
steps.description: Unfold your fabric so that you have two trumpet shapes. Stack them together with the right sides facing in. Make sure that all of the edges are aligned. You can put your pencil skirt away now.

steps.headline: Sew along the sides using a ⅝-inch (1.59-centimeter) seam allowance.
steps.description: Start sewing along the top corner of your skirt all the way down to the bottom. When you reach the corner between the knees and the flare, pause, turn your fabric, and continue sewing. Do not sew across the top and bottom hems. Remember to backstitch at the start and end of you sewing. Do not turn your skirt right side out just yet.

steps.headline: Sew ½-ich (1.27-centimeter) wide elastic to waist.
steps.description: Cut the elastic 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) longer than your hip measurement. Pin it around the top edge of your skirt, then overlap the two ends by ½-inch (1.27-centimeter). Sew the elastic to the fabric using a zigzag stitch and a matching thread color. Remove the pins as you sew.

steps.headline: Fold and sew the waist down.
steps.description: Fold the top edge down by ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) so that you can't see the elastic anymore. Sew the hem down using another zigzag stitch. Remember to backstitch at the start and end of your sewing.

steps.headline: Hem the bottom of your skirt.
steps.description: Fold the bottom edge by ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) and press it flat with an iron. Fold it by another ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) and press it flat once more. Sew along the inside folded edge using a ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) seam allowance. Backstitch at the start and end of your sewing.

steps.headline: Turn your skirt right side out.
steps.description: It is now ready to wear!
